Welcome to Undergraduate Achievement

Please begin this module by reviewing the module handbook. You will find additional information such as the weekly schedule, learning methods, and essential resources. Students are responsible for reading the content of this document. For further information, contact your instructor

View module handbook

Module Outline

Academic writing, research, and conduct skills for pre-university students as a foundation for success in higher education.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

.

Apply principles of academic integrity when producing work at the University.

.

Demonstrate understanding of proper use of source material, critical argumentation, and coherent writing.

.

Create written assignments in English which meet required standards for undergraduate study.

.

Use techniques for expressing a flow of ideas and following a logical written structure.

Assessments

  • Quizzes: Weekly individual quizzes: 75%25 (15%25 per quiz)

  • Video submission: Final group video submission: 25%25

Assessment dates

Please note and manage your submission dates, they are important, and you must submit your assessments before the deadline. It is NOT possible to request an extension. The University will NOT send reminders if your submission is late or if you do not submit at all. If there are exceptional circumstances outside your control (for example, serious illness) affecting your ability to submit on time, you can download an Exceptional Circumstances (EC) formLinks to an external site..

Teaching team

.

Don Hickerson

Don completed a Bachelor's degree in Business Administration from Confederation College (Canada) and an Honours degree in Sociology from Lakehead University. During this time, an Internship at the Vietnam National University greatly altered his research focus, which he used to complete a Master of Sociology at the University of Western Ontario and continue this as a PhD student.

Contact

Email: don.h@buv.edu.vn

.

Maren Viol

Originally from Germany, Maren holds an undergraduate degree in International Hospitality Management from Stenden University in the Netherlands and an MSc in Tourism and Events from the University of Sunderland in the UK. Maren gained her PhD from Edinburgh Napier University in the UK in 2016 with a thesis exploring commemorative narratives of the anniversary events of the fall of the Berlin Wall. Since then, she has taught on tourism, hospitality and events management courses in the UK and Vietnam and has held programme leadership roles at undergraduate and postgraduate levels. Maren is also a Fellow of Advance HE. Her research interests include commemoration, memory studies, semiotics, tourism education and sustainable tourism.

Contact

Email: maren.v@buv.edu.vn

.

Michael Lomax

Raised and educated in the North-East of England, Michael completed a Bachelor's degree in Advertising and Media from Northumbria University, Newcastle. Following graduation in 2012, he was employed for 5 years in the UK music events and hospitality industry as a Marketing and Events Manager. During this time, Michael continued to pursue his passion for marketing by undertaking a Master's degree in Mass Communications Management, which he completed in 2013. In 2017, he moved into a corporate marketing management role for Parmley Graham Ltd, the largest industrial automation partner company for Siemens UK, transitioning to education in Vietnam and specialising in Digital Marketing and Social Media Marketing Management.

Contact

Email: michael.l@buv.edu.vn

.

Francesco Meca

Francesco holds a Master of Business Administration, a Master's degree in Project and Information Management, and a Bachelor's degree in Economics and Business Management.In a career that spans more than 20 years, he worked in marketing, operations, logistics, I.T. and strategic management consulting, receiving appreciation from professionals from all around the world, at all levels, for organizations of all sizes (among which, Apple), in different industries. Growingly involved in social entrepreneurship, he has mentored and provided advisory for several award-winning business projects, some of which are in programmes backed by the United Nations, also authoring magazine articles on philosophy, social inclusion and technology

Contact

Email: francesco.m@buv.edu.vn

week1.body:
Welcome to week 1

This week we will look at academic integrity. By the end of this lesson you should be able to define academic integrity, identify 5 criteria for evaluating source credibility, and understand what paraphrasing is.

.

LESSON CONTENT

  1. prework: Read Part I of the course textbook. Essential features of academic writing

  2. Class 1: Lecture: After introducing ourselves, let's get started with academic integrity. We'll learn about what it is and how to avoid it, including websites to stay away from and what browsers you should use to conduct research.

  3. Class 2: Canvas Info Session and Workshop

  4. Class 3: Practical activity

  5. Class 4: Wrap up and Quiz

.

STUDY MATERIALS

  • Self-check: What is good academic conduct according to Staffordshire University?

  • Read: Find out when to paraphrase and when to summarise

  • Play: Defeat the plagiarism Goblins!

  • Lecture Slides: Review this week's lecture ppt

.

Ask questions, view comments, and get follow-up materials on the course noticeboard

week2.body:
Welcome to week 2

Writing and information skills are an immensely important and powerful tool in the academic world. This week we will discover the process of university writing and academic research as tools for success.

.

LESSON CONTENT

  1. Prework: Read Part II of the course textbook

  2. Session 1: Research and Library Skills.

  3. Session 2: Source Evaluation and Annotated Bibliography

  4. Session 3: Research Easter Egg Hunt. Uncovering Knowledge in the Library

.

STUDY MATERIALS

  • Lecture Slides: Review this week's lecture ppt

  • Activity 1: Source Evaluation and Annotated Bibliography

  • Activity 2: Research Easter Egg Hunt: Uncovering Knowledge in the Sources

  • Training Slides : Library Skill Workshop

.

Ask questions, view comments, and get follow-up materials on the course noticeboard

week3.body:
Welcome to week 3

This week will help students understand different types of University Assessment and Academic Writing tips.

.

LESSON CONTENT

  1. Prework: Read textbook

  2. Session 1: Lecture

  3. Session 2: Written Assignments

  4. Session 3: Exploring the Art of Academic Writing and Understanding Formality in Different Disciplines

.

STUDY MATERIALS

  • Lecture Slides: Review this week's lecture ppt

  • Activity S2: Written Assignments

  • Activity S3: Writing Sample

  • Video : Why you procrastinate even when it feels bad

.

Ask questions, view comments, and get follow-up materials on the course noticeboard

week4.body:
Welcome to week 4

The term critical comes from the Greek word kritikos meaning "able to judge or discern". Critical thinking is the ability to think clearly and rationally about what to do or what to believe. It includes the ability to engage in reflective and independent thinking. A skill required for success at university.

.

LESSON CONTENT

  1. Prework: Read textbook

  2. Session 1: Lecture

  3. Session 2: Critical Thinking Exercise

  4. Session 3: QA for the assessment

.

STUDY MATERIALS

  • Lecture Slides: Review this week's lecture ppt

  • Activity : Critical Thinking Task

  • Read: Mass Media Impact on Opinion Evolution in Biased Digital Environments

  • Watch: Sample Approach

.

Ask questions, view comments, and get follow-up materials on the course noticeboard

week5.body:

Review principles of academic integrity, citation and referencing, paraphrasing, plagiarism.

.

.

STUDY MATERIALS

.
